indication: often used for pulmonary, SSSI, and intraabdominal infections
to_know: effective against M. tuberculosis (second line agent)
Other:
primarily eliminated in feces (hepatic) 

low urinary excretion-only FQ not used to treat UTIs 

no dosage adjustment is necessary in patients with renal impairment

Pronunciation: sul fa meth OKS a zole & trye METH oh prim
forms: powder for IV, tablet (co-formulated with TMP)
indication: resistance in streptococcus (e.g., do not use for strep throat), but effective against MSSA and many CA-MRSA strains \n\neffective for many Enterobacteriaceae (PEK bugs)
star: resistance development to TMP-SMX is limited by the 2 drugs acting synergistically blocking sequential steps in folic acid synthesis
to_know: sulfonamide resistance is the result of mutation or increased expression of dihydropteroate synthetase\n\ninhibiting 2 different steps reduces the likelihood that resistance will develop; however, as with most antibacterial agents, resistance is still a problem

indication: used for bacterial infections such as pneumonia, bronchitis, and infections of the ear, nose, throat, skin, and urinary tract
to_know: effective against a wide range of bacteria
